A sample rule for illustrative purpose:  " PetalLength > 2.6  AND  PetalWidth > 1.65  AND  SepalLength > 6.6  " Class: setosa.  This is the rule I worked with

Ok, so I have made some progress on this. The following is what I have got:  rule.v <-rules[2,]
# Generate the query
query <- paste("SELECT Species, count(Species) FROM dataset WHERE ", rule.v, " group by Species", sep="")
# Execute and print the results
print(sqldf(query))  Here rules is the dataset of rules I have, which is over 1000. I am working with the iris dataset, and Species is the target variable. So this is giving me the kind of output I want, but I wish to now use the same query on all the rules. How can I get the print command to be stored in a data frame with all the values?

What I don't like on these more "correct" ways is that this is not the way I normally use data.frames. The df@data[1, 'zinc'] is close to what I use normally. And more importantly, with @data you can work with it as a dataframe - indexing multiple columns by name or index: meuse@data[,c('zinc','cadmium')] unfortunatelly would not work in the meuse[[]] form.

Thanks! 1) so you think it is a bug that those 3 statements do not work? Can someone fix it? 2) is the @data feature of Spatial*DataFrame documented somewhere? One could take this as a criteria wheter it is reasonable to use it. It seems that they also use the form df[['zinc']][1] intro_sp vignette.

I have tried using the sqldf package, however, the issue I am facing is that a rule can't be read back as a rule into R. What I can do is unlist(rule, use.names = FALSE)[-1], which gives me the attributes from the rule like "PetalLength > 4.95" "PetalWidth > 1.75". I want to use these aspects from each rule and then pass them through the dataframe to see which elements are classified correctly, and which ones incorrectly.

It's because it is for developers to hide inside the code they provide to users, i.e. it's subverting the API if you don't use the methods provided. There's no danger in it, except that the developers might change the API and your code won't work (I think it's safe in this instance but avoid it generally if you can. The Spatial* classes should have done more to help here, it might be because  the DataFrame part was originally implemented separately, before extending the actual data.frame in R, long story I guess).

All free scales will do is allow the ranges to vary. But faceting is , by definition, intended for when the scales are essentially the same. You're proposing entirely different orderings, hence entirely different scales. The only option I know of is to use grid.arrange as mentioned below.

A few comments... you can do data.table() instead of as.data.table(as.data.frame()), your bigram tokeniser is set to get one-grams and two-grams which will result in more than double counting (mine just does 2-grams, and then I subset to remove duplicates), and I'm curious what is the advantage of data.table here? My answer is just vectors and sparse matrices, I'm not sure if you gain much in speed or memory by using data.table, have you benchmarked?

you can pass widths = unit(c(1, 2, 3), "null") to arrangeGrob, and tweak the relative factors manually.

meuse$zinc[1] <- NA  It seems that other pathways to this are not provided as methods, but they could be added. I'll have a look into that. You could expect that meuse[1,'zinc'] <- NA, meuse[1,][['zinc']] <- NA, and meuse[1,]$zinc <- NA should all work. It's probably best to avoid the @ operator if you can.

If you want Dates, use as.Date. If you want times, use as.POSIXct. Don't convert to POSIXlt unless you need to extract a component (hours, minutes, etc.) Don't use POSIXlt with a data.frame because it is a list which is slower and uses more memory than POSIXct.
as.POSIXlt is vectorized, so df$time <- from.timestamp(df$time) should work.
Those are probably the row names and not a column.

Hello and welcome to SO.  Generally, the questions here are regarding concrete programming obstacles.  While I hate to vote to close a question for a first post, this really is something that is easily found with a basic search.

You can read your file as usual (say SplitMe <- read.csv("test.csv")). Then, presuming your third column is called "V3", you can use read.fwf(file=textConnection(SplitMe$V3), widths = rep(1, 20)) to split it. Combining the two: cbind(SplitMe[-3], read.fwf(file=textConnection(SplitMe$V3), widths = rep(1, 20)) should do it with this example. Replace the numbers as needed for your actual data.
strsplit should work fine with split = "".

Making new data frames for a new layer, or creating whole new variables is what you signed up for when you started using ggplot. It isn't called "the grammar of graphics" for nothing. If what you try isn't grammatically correct, well...

Ditto to what @joran said. If you're going to have varying column names, you can use aes_string to deal with your mod_ws variable: aes_string(x='Date_Rank', y=mod_ws)...

@SeñorO, I agree. I think load might have been written back in the days when we still thought attach() was a good idea too.

@BenBolker the command created a .csv file, but added a column numbering rows. For example, excel column "A" row 1 displays nothing, row 2 displays 1, row 3 displays 2, ect. Deleting column "A" and moving the other 4 rows over fixed the problem.
If you run the command line by line, you don't need the multiline option. But if you have read the entire file into $subject, then you do need it.

That approach makes more sense, I just find it frustrating that load creates an object in your workspace in the same way <<- would inside a function. Personally I think load should return the object itself.
Why do you need the multiline option? I ran this in the command line: perl -p -e 's/(?<!,)(?<!^)"(?!,|$)/""/mg;' file1.csv > file2.csv

Then use cbind( rownames(df.coef), df.coef). And saying a function "doesn't like that" is not particularly helpful. If the problem is that the rownames are lost then the cbind maneuver will work. If the problem is that the rownames create an error, then you are toast, since dataframes always have rownames.

Rewritten the answer. I think you're better off writing your own methods, though.

The issue is that R is parsing your string before sending it onto the regex function.  That means the \ gets read as an instruction by the R parser.  You have to use \\ to tell R that the \ is literal and to pass \ to the regex.

Oops, left out the != 0 in the row sums. It's as @Cnrl explained. Dropping rows with 80% or more zeros is the same as keeping rows with 20% or more nonzeros.

This will, of course, create a list for the third column. Perhaps cbind(fileContents, do.call(rbind, strsplit(fileContents[, 3], ""))) might be more "typical user expectation" (but would also depend on the data being rectangular in order to work).

I would guess it's plotting in the background and opening a new device for each value of n or then you have opened graphical devices with your plot.new and png calls that exist in your code (I only ran my own independent example due to not having your data). Try running few dev.off()'s to close down any possible png devices or restart your session. If your code has been interrupted due to an error it may be that there are a lot of open devices that were never closed due to code interruption.

The start of my post attempts to explain why your h(n) didn't work - I was posting as you edited. Both n and x cannot be vectors, and I think your code implicitly incorporated a vector for x values. I now edited my answer so that I show how you could test multiple n-values by calling each n value separately with the wrapper function. In essence, it is doing many calls: wrapper(i=1, x=xs, n=nseq[1], fti=fti1); wrapper(i=1, x=xs, n=nseq[2], fti=fti1), etc where nseq is your vector of n values 0:256. For each distribution I would perform this separately, so that I change the i and fti values.

And this solution will be much faster than using substring function.

@nacnudus you'd better remove the figure directory before you run knitr again; there are a lot of dark facts about LaTeX, e.g. it prefers PNG over PDF by default, so if there are a foo.png and a foo.pdf, \includegraphics{foo} will use foo.png
